text.p: The manager of a supermarket tracked the amount of time needed for customers to be served by the cashier. After checking with his statistics professor, he concluded that the checkout times are exponentially distributed with a mean of \($mu\) minutes. What propotion of customers require more than \($a\) minutes to check out?

ul.li: What is the probability that exactly \($k\) customers were serviced between 10am and 10:10am ? (Hint, this number has a Poisson distribution).

text.p: (we count customers whose service started between 10am and 10:10am but not customers whose service period started before 10am and ended after 10am)
